isis.stitle: VT-365 Diesel Engine Diagnostics (2002) - HARD START AND NO START DIAGNOSTICS - Test Procedures - Low ICP System Pressure

svcprocinfo.para: To determine the cause of low ICP pressure that prevents engine starting

item.para: Electronic Service Tool (EST) with Master Diagnostics
International® EZ-Tech Interface Cable
DMM
Actuator breakout harness
Pressure sensor breakout harness
No. 6 leak test plug
No. 10 leak test plug (2)
IPR isolation adapter
Test adapter for high pressure rail
Test adapter for high pressure pump cover
No. 6 release tool
No. 8 and No. 10 release tool (combined)
Shallow socket (12 point 19 mm) with extension
Compressor air source 689 kPa (100 psi)

warning.para: To avoid serious personal injury, possible death, or damage to the engine or vehicle, read all safety instructions in the foreword of this manual. Follow all warnings, cautions, and notes.

svcprocinfo.para: If there are no concerns with lube oil pressure, start Test 16.1 (System Function)

figure.caption: Actuator breakout harness installed to IPR

step1.para: Install actuator breakout harness to IPR. (Do not connect engine harness.)
Apply ground and B+ volts to the IPR valve.

caution.para: Do not leave the IPR valve energized longer than 120 seconds - this can damage the IPR valve.

warning.para: To avoid serious personal injury, possible death, or damage to the engine or vehicle - comply with the following:
While cranking the engine, the engine could start. Make sure the parking brake is set, the transmission is in neutral, and the wheels are blocked.

note.para: If the engine starts, disconnect B+ or ground at the actuator breakout harness.

step1.para: Crank the engine and monitor ICP using the EST or (DMM and pressure sensor breakout harness).
Record results (System Function) on Hard Start and No Start Diagnostics form.

item.para: If ICP increases above 3.45 MPa (500 psi) (.82v), the mechanical system is operating correctly for the engine to start. ICP can increase to 21.00 MPa (3,000 psi) (3.6v). Do not continue with ICP system diagnostics.
Check DTCs found during Test 8. (Make sure problems were corrected.)
For problems in the electrical circuit, see IPR Circuit Diagnostics in Section 7.
If 3.45 MPa kPa (500 psi) (.82v) can not be reached, continue with the following test IPR Isolation (16.2).

step1.para: Remove the oil fill cap from left valve cover to make it easier to hear leaks and prevent unintended pressurization of the crankcase.
Unplug connector for fuel injector 7.

Use a shallow socket (12 point 19 mm) to release the pass through connector; push the pass through connector down (not too far) until the O-ring is almost completely out of the bore. (This makes it easier to hear leaks inside the right hand valve cover.)
Remove bolts from the high pressure heat shield. (Let heat shield rest on rear cover.)
Remove plug from rear of the high pressure pump cover.
Install IPR isolation adapter, connect line for shop air, and apply 689 kPa (100 psi).
Listen for air leaks inside the left and right valve covers.
Record result on the diagnostics form.

item.para: If a leak is not heard in the left or right valve cover, remove IPR isolation adapter and continue with IPR function (16.3).

note.para: If a leak cannot be distinguished, remove the valve cover for right side first. (Both valve covers may have to be removed to complete the tests.)

item.para: If a leak is isolated in the left or right valve cover, see Step 9.

step1.para: Remove isolation adapter from high pressure pump cover and install plug.
Install oil fill cap, reseat injector pass through connector, and connect No. 7 injector.
Reinstall heat shield

caution.para: The heat shield is installed to prevent failure of the ICP sensor and the IPR.

step1.para: Continue with Cylinder Head Isolation (16.4) for the side that leaks air.
Install ICP system adapter .
Install IPR isolation adapter, connect line for shop air, apply 689 kPa (100 psi), and listen for leaks.
Record results on VTv365 Hard Start and No Start Diagnostics form.

item.para: A leak should be heard. Air should be passing through the IPR valve when the IPR valve is not energized.

step1.para: Use actuator breakout harness to apply B+ and ground to the IPR valve.
Record results on the diagnostics form.

item.para: When the IPR valve is energized, the air leak should stop.
If the leak is still heard, replace the IPR valve following procedures in the Engine Service Manual, and repeat test for IPR Function.
If leak is not heard, continue with Step 6.

step1.para: Remove actuator breakout harness and reconnect engine harness.
Remove ICP system adapter from high pressure pump cover and install plug.
Install oil fill cap, reseat injector pass through connector, and connect No. 7 injector.
Crank engine and monitor ICP, using EST or (DMM and pressure sensor breakout harness).

item.para: If engine does not start and engine pressure does not reach 3.45 MPa (500 psi), continue with test for High Pressure Pump (16.6).
If the engine starts, shut the engine down and install heat shield.

caution.para: The heat shield is installed to prevent failure of the ICP sensor and the IPR.

step1.para: Remove valve cover for suspected side, following procedures in the Engine Service Manual.

note.para: If a leak cannot be distinguished, remove the valve cover for right side first. (Both valve covers may have to be removed to complete the tests.)

figure.caption: Releasing high pressure oil line from high pressure tube

step1.para: Use No. 6 release tool to disconnect oil line from the connection tube.
Install No. 6 leak test plug into the oil line.

figure.caption: High pressure rail test adapter installed

step1.para: Remove air bleed plug from the high pressure oil rail and install test adapter.
Connect shop air and apply 689 kPa (100 psi).
Check high pressure oil line, check fitting, high pressure oil rail, and fuel injectors for leaks.
Record results on Hard Start and No Start Diagnostics form.

item.para: If leaks were detected repair as needed.
If leaks were not detected for the suspect side, repeat procedure for the opposite side.
If leaks were not detected for both sides continue with Step 8.

step1.para: Remove No. 6 leak test plug from high pressure line and reconnect line to connection tube.
Remove test adapter from oil rail and reinstall bleed screw.
Do the following test for Discharge, Rear branch, and Connection Tubes (16.5).

svcsubproc.title: Discharge, Rear Branch , and Connection Tubes (16.5)
svcsubproc.para: At this point both valve covers are removed.

figure.caption: Releasing high pressure oil line from high pressure rail

step1.para: Use No. 10 - No. 8 combination release tool to disconnect high pressure oil line from the high pressure rail on left and right sides.
Install No. 10 leak test plug in high pressure oil line for left and right sides.
Remove bolts from the high pressure heat shield. (Let heat shield rest on rear cover.)
Remove plug from rear of high pressure pump cover.
Install IPR isolation adapter, connector, and apply 689 kPa (100 psi) and listen for air leaks.
Record results on Hard Start and No Start Diagnostics form.

item.para: If a leak is heard continue with Step 7.
If an internal leak is not heard, check earlier test results.

step1.para: Remove and check high pressure connection tubes for defects.

item.para: If connection tubes are good, reinstall the connection tubes, and connect high pressure oil lines.
If a connection tube is defective, replace the connection tube.

figure.caption: Under side of high pressure pump cover

step1.para: Remove and check high pressure pump cover for defects in the discharge tube bore.

figure.caption: D-ring on high pressure pump discharge tube

step1.para: Check D-ring on the high pressure discharge tube for damage.

figure.caption: Applying shop air to high pressure discharge tube

step1.para: Verify that No. 10 plugs are still in high pressure oil line.
Use rubber tipped blow gun to apply shop air into the discharge tube and listen for air leaks.)

item.para: While under pressure, inspect and check discharge tube and quick disconnect coupling on the rear branch tube.
If the origin of the leak is undetectable, the rear branch tube is leaking into the crankcase. (Replace the tube for the rear branch and retest.)
Before reassembling the engine, make sure the IPR isolation adapter is removed from the pump cover.

step1.para: Remove isolation adapter from the high pressure pump cover, install plug, and install pump cover.
Install heat shield.

caution.para: The heat shield is installed to prevent failure of the ICP sensor and the IPR.

figure.caption: Releasing high pressure oil line from high pressure rail

step1.para: Remove left and right valve covers following procedures in the Engine Service Manual.
Use No. 10 - No. 8 combination release tool to disconnect high pressure oil line from the high pressure rail on left and right sides.
Install No. 10 leak test plug in high pressure oil line for left and right sides.

caution.para: Do not leave the IPR valve energized longer than 120 seconds - this can damage the IPR valve.

step1.para: Use actuator breakout harness to apply B+ and ground to the IPR valve.

warning.para: To avoid serious personal injury, possible death, or damage to the engine or vehicle - comply with the following:
While cranking the engine, the engine could start. Make sure the parking brake is set, the transmission is in neutral, and the wheels are blocked.

note.para: If the engine starts, disconnect B+ or ground at the actuator breakout harness.

step1.para: Crank engine and monitor ICP, using EST or (DMM and pressure sensor breakout harness).
If 3.45 MPa (500 psi) (.82v) can not be reached and leaks are not detected, replace the high pressure pump following procedures in the Engine Service Manual and retest.
